BIRDEE your idea of being incinerated under 400 miles is a bit flawed...It all depends on the yeild. you would have have to be in the immediate blast zone to be incinerated.  The Tsar bomb turned out to have a yield of 51 megatons. almost double what was predicted, however it was only half of what it could have been. Had it had its uranium 238 component, it could have easily been a 100 megaton weapon. But at 51 megatons, it was only capable of causing 3rd degree burns from the epicenter up to around 60 miles away. The interesting thing about the Tsar bomb, is that it's blastwave was recorded all the way around the world...

I didn't learn anything new in this video, other than the fact that cataracts can be a side effect of nuclear blasts. The video states very well known facts about nuclear blasts without adding particularly interesting or surprising observations. I find the subject matter to be very interesting and worth exploring further, though, so I hope it is investigated to a greater depth in later videos.
